awd_titl_txt: Integrating System Physics with Sensor Data for Health Prognostics of Complex Engineered Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will advance the Nation's economic welfare by improving the reliability and energy-efficiency of modern Data Center (DC) operations.  As computational needs increase in the era of artificial intelligence (AI) and big data, DCs are becoming larger consumers of energy and currently reflect 2 percent of the US energy market.  Within the DC, the cooling systems make up 30-40 percent of the total energy consumption.  Cooling system failures are critical and cause interruptions on massive cloud/mobile services provided by large corporations such as Microsoft, IBM, Amazon, Netflix, etc. This award will investigate the integration of physics-based and data-driven methods for the modeling and prognostics of complex systems as represented by DC cooling systems.  The project includes activities to broaden interest, especially among underrepresented groups, in STEM fields including applied probability and statistics, reliability engineering and data-analytics through hands-on activities and internship opportunities provided by the industry collaborators. Integrating research outcomes into education and support of graduate students will nurture a pool of next-generation data scientists and engineers for the northwest Arkansas and rural Virginia regions. 

This project will develop and validate novel methods to enable the integration of fundamental system physics and sensor monitoring data for the modeling and prognostics of complex engineering systems. The project consists of three connected research thrusts. Thrust 1 will establish a flexible two-layer physical-statistical modeling framework which enables the integration of system physics into the modeling and interpretation of sensor monitoring data. The connection between Gaussian Process (GP) regression, dynamical models, and Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) Stochastic Difference Equations (SDE) will be established in order to exploit advantages in modeling, computation and interpretation.  Thrust 2 will develop a new class of multivariate stochastic models to capture the complex dynamics and dependency among multiple system health state variables. Thrust  3 will perform comprehensive validation, testing and continuous improvement of the project's methods based on real datasets provided by IBM, Arkansas High Performance Computing Center (AHPCC-UARK), and Virginia Tech Advanced Research Computing facilities (ARC-VT). This research is expected to lead to interpretable data-driven models, actionable engineering insights and explainable operational decisions with tangible impacts on the health prognostics of complex engineering systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated and established a statistical modeling framework for the health prognostics of complex (mechanical) engineering systems by considering both system working principles and multiple sensor monitoring signals. The framework utilizes system working principles as regularity conditions in a "non-intrusive" manner (by imposing constraints on the relationship among multiple sensor signals) and consists of a data layer and a physics layer (i.e., a dynamical model). The data layer captures the statistically correlated temporal dynamics of hidden system states (e.g., degradation), while the physics layer imposes regularization among hidden system states by invoking the relationship between multiple observed system operating parameters and system health states. The proposed approach addresses some common challenges arising from the health prognostics of engineered systems, including the filtering of hidden system health states from monitored system operation parameters, and the statistical dependency among the temporal dynamics of multiple system state variables. The model accounts for the statistical dependence among system states, and captures the complex dependence structure by the Archimedean family of copulas approximated by a cubic B-splines. In the numerical application involving real chiller operating data, the proposed physics-based statistical model has been constructed for estimating the system internal states. The results explained the decrease in the observed cooling efficiency caused by the degradation of system internal states, and uncovered the complex correlation structure between system states. Through the modeling of the dependence of system internal states, the numerical findings illustrated the advantages of capturing the complex correlation structure by a general family of copulas with the generator function approximated non-parametrically. As sensor data become more readily available in applications, the proposed approach is also a demonstration of how statistical models can be constructed for complex mechanical systems, i.e., developing an understanding the working principles behind an engineering system, introducing model components to reflect the most important features of system state degradation, and deriving an intuitive data-driven method for parameter estimation which is as simple as possible.

This research has generated eight research papers on top journals in engineering statistics, quality and reliability, including Journal of Quality Technology, Journal of the Royal Statistical Society (Series C), Naval research logistics, Technometrics, Reliability Engineering and System Safety, and Journal of Applied Statistics. Among these papers, one was recently selected as the finalists of the Best Paper Competition of the Quality, Statistics and Reliability at INFORMS Annual Meeting, Indianapolis, Oct 2022. Another paper won the 2022 SPES and Q&P Student Paper Competition from the American Statistical Association. 

Research outcomes have also been integrated into education activities, including the course "Statistical Learning for Industry Applications" at University of Arkansas, the course "Statistical Methods for Reliability Data" at Virginia Tech, and two two-hour tutorial sessions at Reliability and Maintainability Symposium 2021 and 2022, entitled "Integrating Physics with Sensor Data for System Health Prognostics". One student has completed the NSF-funded intern with the National Renewable Energy Lab (NREL) and Argonne National Lab in 2021 and 2022. Two students, who were funded by this project, are now with the Bank of America and Sanofi Pasteur as Quantitative Operations Associate and Biostatistician.


Last Modified: 11/22/2022
Modified by: Xiao Liu
